Playing this game, I experienced moments of genuine disbelief at how good it looks. In a game about mystery, the biggest mystery for me is what variety of arcane magic they used to get graphics like this on the Quest. And I'm not just talking about texture resolutions and polygon counts etc. It's also the artistry with which it's all been put together - the design of the artifacts, the animations. While many of the puzzle devices you interact with are elaborate in their design, the solutions are typically very straightforward. Often you're presented with a complex array of switches, dials, sliders etc. and you think it's going to be a real head-scratcher, but then you notice that the solution is inscribed right next to the puzzle. In several cases, I managed to unlock these intricate-looking puzzle boxes just by blindly poking and prodding at different parts. I wasn't even trying to unlock them at this point, I was just playing with the moveable parts to get a sense of what kind of puzzle I was dealing with. And then the puzzle just solved itself. In many cases there are somewhat cryptic clues in the environment, but you don't really need to find the clues because cycling through all the possible combinations takes mere seconds. And in case anyone's wondering, I played with the "hints" option turned off from the start. (It's amazing to me that this opinion is even available, given how much hand-holding the game does anyway). To be fair, there were one or two hard puzzles per chapter, and I really appreciate the thought that went into them. Getting stuck for a while and then finally cracking these puzzles was very satisfying. But overall the A-to-B nature of the problem-solving was disappointing. This game could easily be twice as long and twice as enjoyable if it had more true puzzles and fewer "put the X-shaped thing in the X-shaped slot" type moments.

Still, it's an amazing experience. Can't wait for the next one.
